title: Condition Basics: What Affects Value
metaTitle: Condition Basics: What Affects Value | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: Learn how condition affects wine and spirits value. Fill levels, label condition, capsules, packaging, and what buyers look for.
summary: Condition significantly affects the value of wine and spirits. Understanding what buyers look for helps you set realistic expectations and present your bottles effectively.

sections.heading: Why Condition Matters
content: Collectors and buyers pay premiums for bottles in excellent condition. Condition indicates how well a bottle has been stored and whether the contents are likely to have aged properly.

Poor condition can reduce value by fifty percent or more compared to the same bottle in pristine condition. For rare wines and spirits, condition can mean the difference between a desirable bottle and one that is difficult to sell.
Understanding condition factors helps you describe your bottles accurately and set realistic expectations.

sections.heading: Fill Levels
content: Fill level is the distance from the closure to the liquid surface. For wine, this is measured from the bottom of the cork. For spirits, from the closure or stopper.

Wine naturally loses small amounts of liquid over decades through the cork. Standard fill level terminology ranges from high fill and into neck (excellent) down to mid shoulder and low shoulder (problematic).
Low fills often indicate storage problems or a compromised cork. Buyers discount or avoid bottles with significantly low fills.
list: Into neck or high fill: Excellent, expected for younger wines
Base of neck: Normal for wines over ten years old
Top shoulder: Acceptable for older wines, slight discount
Mid shoulder: Significant concern, substantial discount
Low shoulder or below: Often unsaleable

sections.heading: Label Condition
content: Label condition affects value, especially for older or collectible bottles. Buyers want labels that are legible, intact, and free from major damage.
Minor scuffing or cellar marks are normal for aged wines and have minimal impact. Significant tears, staining, or fading reduce value. Missing labels make bottles difficult to authenticate and sell.
Back labels, if present, should also be legible. For older bottles, original labels with period-appropriate printing and wear are actually preferred over suspiciously pristine labels.
list: Pristine: Clean, no damage, fully legible
Lightly scuffed: Minor wear, negligible impact
Bin soiled: Cellar marks, acceptable for older wines
Stained or torn: Noticeable damage, value reduction
Missing or illegible: Significant problem

sections.heading: Capsules and Seals
content: The capsule covers the cork and closure. For wine, look for intact capsules without cuts, corrosion, or evidence of seepage. For spirits, check that seals are unbroken.
Capsule damage can indicate improper opening attempts, storage issues, or age-related deterioration. Minor wear is normal. Significant damage raises questions.
Seepage stains or sticky residue around the capsule suggest the cork has leaked at some point. This is a significant condition concern.
list: Intact capsule with no cuts or damage
No corrosion or oxidation
No seepage stains or sticky residue
Unbroken tax stamps or seals for spirits
Proper closure with no signs of tampering

sections.heading: Original Packaging
content: Original wood cases (OWC), cardboard boxes, tubes, and presentation packaging add value. For some bottles, original packaging can add ten to twenty percent or more.
Keep all original packaging even if it seems damaged or unimportant. Collectors value provenance, and original packaging helps establish authenticity.
Photograph packaging clearly. Note if cases are complete with all bottles or have gaps.

sections.heading: Storage History
content: Provenance, or the documented history of storage, matters especially for older wines. Bottles stored in professional cellars or known collections are worth more than bottles of unknown origin.
Temperature stability is crucial for wine. Bottles stored in fluctuating temperatures, warm environments, or direct sunlight may have deteriorated regardless of fill level.
If you know the storage history, share it. Purchase receipts, cellar records, and storage facility documentation all help establish provenance.
list: Professional cellar storage preferred
Temperature-controlled home storage acceptable
Documentation of purchase and storage helpful
Unknown storage history reduces value
Signs of heat damage or light exposure problematic

faqs.question: Can I sell bottles with condition issues?
faqs.answer: Often yes, at reduced prices. Let us know about condition concerns upfront. We evaluate each bottle individually.

faqs.question: How do I photograph fill levels?
faqs.answer: Hold the bottle upright, in good light, and photograph so the liquid line is visible against the glass. Include the neck and shoulder in the frame.

faqs.question: Does slight label damage matter?
faqs.answer: Minor scuffing has minimal impact. Significant tears, staining, or missing labels reduce value substantially.

faqs.question: What if I do not know the storage history?
faqs.answer: Just say so. Unknown provenance affects value for older wines but does not prevent a sale.

faqs.question: Should I clean dusty bottles?
faqs.answer: Leave them as is. Cellar dust can actually help establish authenticity. Aggressive cleaning can damage labels.

faqs.question: Does condition matter for spirits?
faqs.answer: Condition matters but less critically than for wine. Fill levels, seal integrity, and packaging are the main factors for spirits.
